contentrichtext.text: {{For|the surname|Chown (surname)}} {{lowercase|title=chown}} The <tt>'''chown'''</tt> [[Command (computing)|command]] (abbreviation for '''ch'''ange '''own'''er) is used on [[Unix-like]] systems to change the owner of a file. In most implementations,{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} it can only be executed by the [[superuser]], to prevent users simply changing ownership of files that aren't theirs to access. [[Privilege (Computing)|Unprivileged]] (regular) users who wish to change the group of a file that they own may use <tt>[[chgrp]]</tt>. ==Usage examples== These examples illustrate typical syntax and use. Modifying permissions requires you are either root or have write access to the file. Changing owner requires root privilege. * Change the owner of <code>/var/run/httpd.pid</code> to 'root' (the standard name for the Superuser). <source lang="bash"> # chown root /var/run/httpd.pid </source> * Change the owner of <code>strace.log</code> to 'rob' and the group identifier to 'developers'. <source lang="bash"> # chown rob:developers strace.log </source> * Change the owner of <code>/tmp</code> and <code>/var/tmp</code> to ‘[[nobody (username)|nobody]]’ (not a good idea), and change the group of <code>/tmp</code> and <code>/var/tmp</code> to ‘[[nogroup (groupname)|nogroup]]’ <source lang="bash"> # chown nobody:nogroup /tmp /var/tmp </source> * Change the group identifier of <code>/home</code> to 512 (regardless of whether a group name is associated with the identifier 512 or not). <source lang="bash"> # chown :512 /home </source> * Change the ownership of <code>base</code> to the user <code>foouser</code> and make it recursive (<code>-R</code>) <source lang="bash"> # chown -R foouser base </source> * Change the ownership to newuser and group to newgroup for all of the files and directories in current directory, and all subdirectories (recursively). <source lang="bash"> # chown -R newuser:newgroup . </source> ==See also== * <code>[[chgrp]]</code> * <code>[[chmod]]</code> * <code>[[takeown]]</code> ==External links== * {{man|cu|chown|SUS}} * [http://nersp.nerdc.ufl.edu/~dicke3/nerspcs/chown.html chown manual page] * [http://www.linfo.org/chown.html The chown Command] by The Linux Information Project (LINFO) {{unix commands}} [[Category:Operating system security]] [[Category:Standard Unix programs]] [[Category:Unix SUS2008 utilities]]
